conclusion: Lowering the light source moves it closer to the plane where shadows fall while maintaining the same horizontal position.
The rays from the light source diverge more strongly as it is lowered.
The ratio of distance-to-shadow to object-height increases as the light height decreases.
Every shadow grows in all directions and its center of gravity shifts farther from the object in the direction opposite the lamp.
A is the ice-cream glass with a tall, slender stem and wide top.
A's shadow will enlarge the most in absolute terms because it is one of the tallest objects.
A's shadow outline is pushed farthest away from the glass, with the bulb-shaped top becoming larger and farther from the stem.
B is the short rectangular typewriter key cluster.
B's shadow enlarges but much less than A due to its low height.
B's shadow slides a short extra distance in the same direction as before, remaining close to the object.
C is the grapefruit with medium height and nearly spherical shape.
C's shadow becomes wider and a little longer.
C's shadow shifts a little farther from the fruit, more than B but less than A and D.
D is the tall vertical blade on a circular base.
D's blade shadow lengthens markedly while keeping its narrow silhouette, and the base's elliptical patch spreads.
D's elongated blade shadow moves appreciably farther from the base, remaining the most clearly separated, elongated shape on the floor.
Lowering the lamp makes every shadow larger and pushes every shadow's footprint farther away from its object.

The amount of change is governed by the object's height: the tallest objects (A and D) lengthen and migrate the most, the medium object (C) shows a moderate increase, and the shortest object (B) shows the smallest change.
